thread.title: Hood Canal Bridge stuck in open position Wednesday
thread.title_full: Hood Canal Bridge stuck in open position Wednesday | The Seattle Times

author: Mike Lindblom
title: Hood Canal Bridge stuck in open position Wednesday
text:
State crews will need an extra hour or more to reopen the Hood Canal Bridge for traffic, perhaps by late Wednesday afternoon, after the drawspan drifted 14 feet out of alignment at 10:30 a.m.
The state initially thought the bridge could be realigned shortly after 2:30 p.m., as the slack, high tide arrived.
But now, a tug operation will wait a bit longer, perhaps until the tide begins to recede, which should aid in towing the drawspan back into place, said Claudia Bingham Baker, spokeswoman for the Washington State Department of Transportation. She was not expecting traffic to resume before 4 p.m.
WSDOT blames the incident on three factors Wednesday morning:
 • One anchor cable, which secures the deck to the canal bottom, is disconnected for a cable-replacement project, and the new one hasn’t been fastened yet.
• The bridge tender opened the drawspan, as required by federal navigation rules, to let a vessel pass through.
• Tides were quickly rising , en route to a roughly 11-foot increase from dawn to afternoon. Moving water pushed against the central, floating segments of the bridge.
The span is part of Highway 104 between Kingston and the Olympic Peninsula, where drivers are being detoured.
“It was an unusual set of circumstances,” Baker said, asked if WSDOT should have anticipated the bridge would misalign.
WSDOT may ask mariners to avoid requesting a drawspan opening, except during slack tide conditions, Baker said. The risk of another misalignment should end within a couple days, when the replacement cable is secured, she said.
Mike Lindblom: 206-515-5631 or mlindblom@seattletimes.com . Twitter @mikelindblom
